final_response:
**Your Apple Tree Health Check – Quick Summary**

| Item | Details |
|------|---------|
| **Disease detected** | **Apple Scab** (high‑confidence 97 %) |
| **Detection method** | AI image analysis using a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) |
| **Is the tree healthy?** | No – the tree shows clear signs of scab. |
| **Immediate action needed** | Fungicide treatment, sanitation, and cultural practices. |

---

## 1. What is Apple Scab?

Apple scab is a fungal disease caused by *Venturia inaequalis*. It appears as dark, scabby lesions on leaves, fruit, and sometimes stems. If left untreated, it can reduce fruit yield, lower quality, and make apples more susceptible to other stresses.

---

## 2. Why the AI diagnosis is reliable

- **97 % confidence** – the CNN model has a very high probability that the symptoms belong to Apple Scab.
- **Top‑3 predictions**: Apple Scab (97 %), Peach Bacterial Spot (2 %), Apple Black Rot (0.3 %). The other possibilities are negligible.

---

## 3. Immediate, practical steps you can take

| Step | What to do | When | Tips |
|------|------------|------|------|
| **1. Inspect the whole orchard** | Look for scabby lesions on leaves, fruit, and bark. | Today | Use a magnifying glass if needed. |
| **2. Prune infected branches** | Remove and discard any heavily infected twigs. | Within 24 h | Keep pruning tools clean (sanitize with 10 % bleach). |
| **3. Apply a fungicide** | Use a registered scab‑control product (e.g., chlorothalonil, mancozeb, or a copper‑based spray). | As soon as possible, then every 7–10 days | Follow label rates; avoid spraying on hot, windy days. |
| **4. Improve air circulation** | Thin out dense canopy, remove deadwood, and ensure good spacing. | Ongoing | This reduces humidity that favors the fungus. |
| **5. Mulch and water management** | Keep the soil moist but not water‑logged; mulch to reduce leaf wetness. | Ongoing | Water at the base, not the canopy. |
| **6. Monitor for new symptoms** | Check weekly for new lesions or fruit damage. | Weekly | Early detection saves more fruit. |
| **7. Consider resistant varieties** | If you’re planning a replant, choose scab‑resistant apple cultivars. | Long‑term | Talk to a local extension agent. |

---

## 4. Where to get the supplies

### Nearby fertilizer & pesticide shops

> **No shops were found in the immediate radius via OpenStreetMap.**  
> However, you can quickly locate suppliers using the Google Maps links below. Just click the link that best matches what you need.

| Search | Google Maps URL |
|--------|-----------------|
| Fertilizer shop | <https://www.google.com/maps/search/fertilizer+shop/@9.9406,76.2653,15z> |
| Agricultural input store | <https://www.google.com/maps/search/agricultural+input+store/@9.9406,76.2653,15z> |
| Agro shop | <https://www.google.com/maps/search/agro+shop/@9.9406,76.2653,15z> |
| Pesticide shop | <https://www.google.com/maps/search/pesticide+shop/@9.9406,76.2653,15z> |
| Seed store | <https://www.google.com/maps/search/seed+store/@9.9406,76.2653,15z> |
| Fertilizer store | <https://www.google.com/maps/search/fertilizer+store/@9.9406,76.2653,15z> |

> **Tip:** If you don’t find what you need within a 15 km radius, widen the search or ask local farmers for recommendations.

---

## 5. Positive reinforcement & next steps

- **You’ve already taken the first step** by using AI to diagnose the problem—great job!  
- **Act quickly**: Apple scab can spread rapidly, but with timely fungicide application and good orchard hygiene, you can protect most of your crop.  
- **Keep a log**: Note dates of treatment, weather conditions, and any new symptoms. This will help you refine your strategy next season.

---

### Quick Checklist (Print or save)

1. Inspect all trees → 2. Prune infected branches → 3. Spray fungicide → 4. Improve airflow → 5. Mulch & water properly → 6. Monitor weekly → 7. Plan for resistant varieties.

Feel free to reach out if you need specific product recommendations or help with a treatment schedule. Happy farming!

final_response:
**Your tomato leaves are showing signs of leaf scorch**  
The AI image‑analysis (via a language‑model review of your description) indicates that the shrunken, dry, brown leaves you’re seeing are typical of **Tomato Leaf Scorch**. This condition is usually triggered by heat stress, drought, or inconsistent watering rather than a pathogen.

---

### Why this happens  
- **Heat stress**: High daytime temperatures can cause rapid water loss.  
- **Drought / uneven watering**: When soil dries out too quickly, the plant pulls water from leaves, leading to shrinkage and browning.  
- **Poor drainage**: Waterlogged soil can also stress the plant, though the symptoms are usually more wilted than shriveled.

---

### Immediate, practical steps you can take

| Action | How to do it | Why it helps |
|--------|--------------|--------------|
| **Check soil moisture** | Stick a finger 2–3 cm into the soil. If it feels dry, water. | Keeps the root zone hydrated, reducing leaf shrinkage. |
| **Water consistently** | Aim for 2–3 cm of water per week (adjust for rainfall). Water early in the morning or late afternoon to reduce evaporation. | Prevents sudden water loss and keeps leaves turgid. |
| **Provide shade** | Use a shade cloth or move pots to a partially shaded spot during the hottest part of the day. | Lowers leaf temperature and reduces transpiration. |
| **Improve drainage** | Ensure pots or beds have drainage holes; add a layer of gravel or coarse sand at the bottom. | Prevents waterlogging and root rot, which can worsen scorch. |
| **Mulch** | Spread 2–3 cm of organic mulch (straw, wood chips) around the base. | Retains soil moisture and moderates temperature. |
| **Avoid over‑fertilizing** | Use a balanced fertilizer at half the recommended rate. | Excess nitrogen can make leaves more susceptible to heat stress. |
| **Monitor for pests** | Check for aphids, whiteflies, or spider mites. Treat if found. | Pests can exacerbate stress symptoms. |

---

### When to seek further help  
- **Leaves become severely browned or die**: Consider a more detailed inspection or a visit to a local extension office.  
- **Symptoms persist after 1–2 weeks of consistent care**: A professional diagnosis (e.g., a local agronomist or a plant pathologist) can rule out other diseases or nutrient deficiencies.

---

### Encouragement & next steps  
Leaf scorch is usually reversible with proper care. By adjusting your watering routine, providing shade, and ensuring good drainage, you’ll likely see the leaves regain their turgor and color within a week or two. Keep a simple log of watering times and weather conditions—this will help you spot patterns and fine‑tune your care routine.

Good luck, and happy tomato growing!

disease_diagnosis.explanation: Shrunken, dry, brown leaves on tomatoes are typical of leaf scorch, often caused by heat stress, drought, or poor watering. The symptoms match the common presentation of this condition.
